Jekyll

Blogging with Jekyll

Posts are Markdown or HTML files within the _posts folder with a filename formatted with year-month-day-title.md such as 2016-02-22-hello-world.md

Writing Posts

The contents of a post is the same as a page, it starts with front matter at the top and the contents of the file. Create a file called _posts/2016-01-01-what-is-coffee.md, then add the front matter followed by the content of the post.

HINT: The date on the blog post needs to be present or past, it can’t be in the future. Weird I know.

Markdown uses shorthand symbols to quickly write articles and then convert it to html. A # symbol creates a h1, two ## creates a h2, etc. To learn more about markdown check out http://www.markdowntutorial.com/lesson/1/

---
layout: post
title: This is a wonderful blog post
---

# This is a wonderful blog post

Wouldn't it be wonderful to read this blog? Absolutely, that's why I've written it.

If you don’t want to use markdown right now, you can also just use standard html.

Creating a Post Layout

We’ve used a new layout, but we need to actually create it before we can use it. So let’s create a second layout. Inside the _layouts.html create a file called post.html

It might sound confusing, but we can actually apply layouts to layouts, so if we want our blog posts to use the same header and footer we can still apply the default layout to post layout and then add additional content on top of it. For example we might create something like this as our post layout:

---
layout: default
---

<section class="grid">
  <div class="col-8 blog-post">

  <h1>{{ page.title }}</h1>

   <p class="date">{{ page.date | date: '%B %d, %Y' }}</p>
   <p class="author">by {{ page.author }}</p>

   {{ content }}

  </div>
  <div class="col-4 sidebar">

    <!-- sidebar content here -->

  </div>
</section>

Listing Blog Posts

The last step is to display our blog posts somewhere, so let’s create a blog.html page. Using a Liquid for loop, we’ll create an element for each post to display all our posts on the blog page:

---

layout: default

title: Blog

---

<h1>Blog</h1>

<div class="blog-posts">

 {% for post in site.posts %}

 <div class="blog-post">
   <h3><a href="{{ post.url }}">{{ post.title }}</a></h3>
   <p class="summary">
     {{ post.category }}
     <span class="date"> {{ post.date | date: '%B %d, %Y' }} </span>
   </p>
   <p> {{ post.excerpt }} </p>
 </div>

 {% endfor %}

</div>

We’ve used a few things here that we haven’t declared in the front matter and that’s because Jekyll has a number of built in variables. url i s the link to the post excerpt is a snippet taken from the start of post content.

Most recent posts

You can cap the number of posts you display in a loop by editing the for loop. This will show the most recent 3 posts.

{% for post in site.posts limit:3 %}
 ...
{% endfor %}

You can also offset it to not show the MOST recent post, but the next 3 recent posts after that one by using an offset ``.

Categories

To create a loop that only displays posts from a specific category, in the yaml of each post (the space between the three dashes at the top) add categories

---
categories:
  - travel
  - food
---

For best practice, before we go further we should add your categories to the _config.yml file. Open up the _config.yml file and add:

categories:
- travel
- lifestyle
- food

Importantly, anytime you make changes to the _config.yml page you need to restart jekyll. So close the terminal, and restart jekyll before going futher.

Then on the page you want to display the posts create this loop to display all the travel photos, replacing … with your content:

{% for post in site.categories.travel %}
 ...
{% endfor %}

To Create Category Archive Pages

There are two options. You can manually create archive pages which is the simplest option if you only have a few categories, or you can use a plugin to auto-generate the category archive pages.

Manually creating category archive pages

Create a new layout called archive.html in the _layouts folder. In the layout add this, along with anything else you want to display.

---
layout: default
---

 <h1>{{page.title}}</h1>

 {% for post in site.categories[page.category] %}

   <div class="blog-post">
     <h3><a href="{{ post.url }}"> {{ post.title }} </a></h3>
     <p class="summary"> {{ post.category }} </p>
     <p class="date"> {{ post.date | date: '%B %d, %Y' }</p>
     <p> {{ post.excerpt }} </p>
   </div>

 {% endfor %}

Then create a folder called archive and inside it create a new html file for each category page you would like to display. For example, this would create a category archive page for travel posts.

---
layout: archive
title: Travel Posts
categories: ['travel']
---

This will then pull in the archive layout and display all of the posts from the travel category. The page will be visible at /archive/travel.html

Automatic Category Archive Pages

Before we get started with the instructions for the category archive plugin, familiarise yourself with jekyll plugins by reading this handy guide.

Before you start using this specific plugin you need to ensure you are ready to start using plugins by setting up your gemfiles and the bundler. To do this, follow the instructions here to install the bundler.

To get started with the jekyll-archives plugin we need to:

  1. Create a file called gemfile
  2. In the gemfile write the following
source 'https://rubygems.org'

gem 'jekyll', '3.1.6'

group :jekyll_plugins do
  gem 'jekyll-archives'
end
  1. Add the following to your site’s _config.yml:
gems:
  - jekyll-archives
  1. Now we need to use terminal to install and activate the gem file. In terminal, navigate to your site folder and then enter gem install bundler.
  2. When using plugins, you need to use bundle exec jekyll serve instead of jekyll serve every time you run jekyll.

Now you’ll still need to create an archive layout for the plugin to use and call it archive.html. Archive pages will automatically be created for you at

    year: '/:year/'
    month: '/:year/:month/'
    day: '/:year/:month/:day/'
    tag: '/tag/:name/'
    category: '/category/:name/'

For example if your website is www.blog.com you would be able to view all posts for January 2017 at www.blog.com/2017/01 and all travel posts at www.blog.com/category/travel.

Pretty Category Tags

Under each post let’s say you want to display each category as a little ‘tag’ that links to that category archive page…

Within your blog post for loop, add the following where you want to output the categories:

{% for category in post.categories %}
  {% assign category_name = category[0] %}
    <a href="/category/{{ category_name | slugify }}/" class="tag">
      {{ category_name | replace: "-", " " }}
    </a>
{% endfor %}

If you want to output a list of all categories, then do the following anywhere on your page:

{% for category in site.categories %}
  {% assign category_name = category[0] %}
    <a href="/category/{{ category_name | slugify }}/" class="tag">
      {{ category_name | replace: "-", " " }}
    </a>
{% endfor %}

This creates a link with a class of tag. The slugify filter removes any spaces so that it can create a working url and the replace filter puts the spaces back for the text of the link.

Then in the CSS you can style each span, like for example:

 .tag {
  font-size: 0.7rem;
  text-transform: uppercase;
  letter-spacing: 1px;
  border: 1px solid rgb(150,150,150);
  color: rgb(150,150,150);
  border-radius: 2px;
  padding: 0.3rem;
  display: inline-block;
  margin: 0.1rem;
  line-height: 1;
}
